options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Rudimentary NLP/text mining skills, a substantive history of USAID programming and administration

We learned about issues facing Sub-Saharan Africa (and other parts of the world), as well as USAID's role in addressing (or attempting to address) these issues. We used R to conduct text analysis on papers surrounding this issue, though a lot of this was done through copy/pasting code rather than learning to write it ourselves.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the content was very interesting - i learned a lot about USAID history and programming

Weaknesses: Professor Barbour was still getting used to teaching on zoom, so sometimes there were technological glitches that meant class had to end early, etc

The course material is fascinating, but Professor Barbour himself is what made this course a highlight of my week. Professor Barbour is incredibly passionate about the issues discussed during class, is an engaging lecturer, has an incredible amount of personal experience in the field, and evidently cares a lot about his students and their learning experience. He shared plenty of anecdotes and went out of his way to make sure students understood all that was being taught (more than any other professor I've had at Yale). No weaknesses aside from the occasional confusion about what readings were to be done before the next class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Barbour did his best, but sometimes the level of engagement on zoom was low.
I thought this class was taught as well as it could have been given the circumstances.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely less work than I expected, but ended up learning a lot regardless! So pretty ideal in that respect. Fascinating coverage of foreign aid and US foreign policy. Certainly not a stats class.

Absolutely. Professor Barbour is fantastic, the material is very interesting, very relevant, and very important to know about. It should be noted that while this course uses R, it is not designed to teach students how to code (rather you simply copy/paste code). This made the coding parts of the course very accessible to students with no coding experience.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
